case_name: Basudev Hazra v. Matiar Rahman Mandal

facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 171 of 1968 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 171 of 1968.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated September 13, 1967 of Calcutta High Court in Criminal Reference No. 36 of 1967.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated September 13, 1967 of the Calcutta High Court in Criminal Reference No. 36 of 1967.

facts.text: N. Mukherjee appeared for the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: N. Mukherjee, for the appellant.

facts.text: The respondent did not appear.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent did number appear.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by Dua, J.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was-delivered by Dua, J.

facts.text: Appellant Basudev Hazra was leaseholder of tolls of public ferry at Sadar Ghat on outskirts of Burdwan town for crossing river Damodar.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, Basudev Hazra, was a leaseholder in respect of tolls of the public ferry at Sadar Ghat on the outskirts of Burdwan town for crossing the river Damodar.

facts.text: Lease was for three years from August 14, 1963 to August 13, 1966, marked Ex. 2.

anchor.surface_text: This lease was for a period of three years  August 14, 1963 to August 13, 1966  Ex. 2.

facts.text: On November 30, 1964, Matiar Rahman Mandal filed a complaint against the appellant in the court of Sadar Sub-Divisional Officer (Judicial), Burdwan.

anchor.surface_text: On November 30, 1964 Matiar Rahman Mandal filed a companyplaint against the appellant in the companyrt of the Sadar Sub-Divisional Officer  Judicial , Burdwan

facts.text: Complaint alleged appellant illegally realised 20 nP. per cart from cultivators driving carts across dry bed of the river.

anchor.surface_text: alleging that the appellant used to realise illegally 20 nP. per cart from the cultivators who used to drive their carts across the dry bed of the river.

facts.text: Matter reported to S.D.O. who directed an enquiry, infuriating the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The matter was reported to the S.D.O. who directed an enquiry. This infuriated the appellant.

facts.text: On November 29, 1964, appellant realised double the amount of toll and threatened complainant with violence on protest.

anchor.surface_text: On November 29, 1964 the appellant realised double the amount of toll and on protest and refusal by the companyplainant he was threatened with violence by the appellant.

facts.text: Magistrate convicted appellant of offences under sections 23 and 24 of Bengal Ferries Act, I of 1885.

anchor.surface_text: The Magistrate trying the appellant for offences under ss. 23 and 24 of the Bengal Ferries Act, I of 1885 companyvincted him of both the offences.

facts.text: Appellant sentenced to fine of Rs. 10/- under s. 23 and Rs. 20/- under s. 24, with simple imprisonment 10 days and 20 days in default.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was sentenced to a fine of Rs. 10/- under s. 23 and to fine of Rs. 20/- under s. 24 in default of payment of fine in the former case he was to undergo simple imprisonment for ten days and in the latter for 20 days.

facts.text: Appellant challenged conviction on revision in Court of Sessions Judge.

anchor.surface_text: On the appellant challenging his companyviction on revision in the Court of the Sessions Judge,

facts.text: Additional Sessions Judge, Burdwan made reference to High Court recommending appellant's acquittal.

anchor.surface_text: the Additional Sessions Judge, Burdwan made a reference to the High Court recommending the appellants acquittal.

facts.text: Appellant's defence: complainants used landing stage and path constructed and repaired by appellant, liable to pay toll.

anchor.surface_text: It was observed by the Additional Sessions Judge in his reference that according to the appellants defence the companyplainants party were in fact using the landing stage and the path companystructed and repaired by him and, therefore, they were liable to pay the usual toll tax.

facts.text: Complainant's case: did not use facilities provided by lessee, used own path, but toll demanded.

anchor.surface_text: the companyplainants case as it appears from the petition of companyplaint and also from the evidence of the three witnesses examined on the point, is that they do number take advantage of any of the facilities provided by the lessee and that the lessee demanded toll from them even though they were using their own path.

facts.text: High Court acquitted appellant under s. 23, no appeal against acquittal.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court accepted the recommendation with respect to the companyviction under s. 23 and acquitted the appellant of that offence. ... We need number refer to the recommendation with respect to the appellants companyviction under s. 23 as this was accepted by the High Court and there is numberappeal against acquittal under that section.

facts.text: High Court upheld conviction under s. 24 based on trial magistrate's findings of realising excess toll and from non-users.

anchor.surface_text: In regard to the companyviction under s. 24 the High Court observed that the trial Magistrate had found  i  that the appellant had been realising toll charges in excess of the scheduled rate of 20 ps. per cart and also realising such charges from persons who did number use the ferry and  ii  that though the companyplainant had number availed of the ferry and had taken the cart over the sandy bed of the river 40 ps. per cart were realised from him.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The present case suffers from numbersuch infirmity. The appeal accordingly fails and is dismissed.

facts.text: Appellant realised 40 ps. per cart from complainant who crossed sandy bed without using ferry.

anchor.surface_text: though the companyplainant had number availed of the ferry and had taken the cart over the sandy bed of the river 40 ps. per cart were realised from him. These findings of fact were held number open to re-examination on revision.

facts.text: Supreme Court found from evidence that appellant delayed prosecution witnesses without due cause.

anchor.surface_text: When the appellants companynsel took us through the evidence we found that the appellant had also delayed the prosecution witnesses without due cause in crossing the river in violation of s. 24.

issues.text: Whether the realisation of toll from persons who do not use the ferry falls within the mischief of s. 24 of the Bengal Ferries Act

anchor.surface_text: and his counsel Mr. D. N. Mukherjee has strenously contended that the realisation of 40 ps. per cart from those who do number use the ferry can number as a matter of law fall within the mischief of s. 24 of the, Bengal Ferries Act. His contention in essence is that unless someone actually uses a ferry numbercharges realised from him for permitting him to cross the river, even if the demand is made by way of toll, can attract the provisions of s. 24.

issues.text: Whether the case amounts to extortion under the Indian Penal Code and does not fall within the purview of s. 24

anchor.surface_text: Repelling the argument that the present was a case of extortion and it did number fall within the purview of s. 24 the High Court [...] number a case of extortion under the Indian Penal Code.

issues.text: Whether the definition of 'ferry' in s. 5 limits the application of s. 24 to actual users of the ferry

anchor.surface_text: Shri Mukherjee drew our attention to s. 5 of the Act in which ferry is defined to include a bridge of boats, pontoons or rafts, a swing-bridge, a flying bridge, a temporary bridge and a landing stage.

issues.text: Whether there is grave miscarriage of justice warranting interference under Art. 136 of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: Art. 136 of the Constitution does number confer a right of appeal on a party. It only confers a discretionary power on this Court to be exercised sparingly to interfere in suitable cases where grave miscarriage of justice has resulted from illegality or from misapprehension or mistake in reading evidence or from ignoring, excluding or illegally admitting material evidence.

issues.text: Whether demanding or taking toll under pretext when not legally due violates s. 24 even from non-users

issues.text: Whether the appellant delayed prosecution witnesses without due cause in violation of s. 24

anchor.surface_text: the appellant had also delayed the prosecution witnesses without due cause in crossing the river in violation of s. 24.

arguments.claim: Realisation of 40 ps. per cart from those who do not use the ferry cannot as a matter of law fall within the mischief of s. 24 of the Bengal Ferries Act unless someone actually uses a ferry

anchor.surface_text: and his counsel Mr. D. N. Mukherjee has strenously contended that the realisation of 40 ps. per cart from those who do number use the ferry can number as a matter of law fall within the mischief of s. 24 of the, Bengal Ferries Act. His contention in essence is that unless someone actually uses a ferry numbercharges realised from him for permitting him to cross the river, even if the demand is made by way of toll, can attract the provisions of s. 24.

arguments.court_reasoning: Section 24 does not speak of taking toll only from users of the ferry; designed to protect against harassment by lessee demanding toll under pretext when not due

arguments.claim: Definition of 'ferry' in s. 5 suggests s. 24 attracted only when a ferry is used and excessive charges realised

anchor.surface_text: Shri Mukherjee drew our attention to s. 5 of the Act in which ferry is defined to include a bridge of boats, pontoons or rafts, a swing-bridge, a flying bridge, a temporary bridge and a landing stage. According to him, this definition suggests that it is only when a ferry is used and excessive, charges realised that s. 24 would be attracted.

arguments.court_reasoning: Definition is not exhaustive and does not control interpretation of s. 24

anchor.surface_text: Forgetting the defence for the moment, it seems to me that numberconviction u s 24 can be sustained on the case of the companyplainant as it is. According to him the companylection of money from the people using their own pathway might amount to extortion but it would number attract s. 24.

arguments.claim: Realisation of 40 ps. falls within mischief of s. 24 which forbids lessee from realising more than lawful toll even when entitled to demand ferry charges

anchor.surface_text: The High Court added that realisation of 40 ps. fell within the mischief of s. 24 which forbids every lessee from realising more than lawful toll even in cases in which he is entitled to demand ferry charges.

arguments.claim: Findings of fact by trial magistrate that appellant realised excess toll and from non-users not open to re-examination on revision

anchor.surface_text: These findings of fact were held number open to re-examination on revision.

arguments.claim: s. 24 covers asking or taking more than lawful toll or delaying without cause, applies to illegal demand under pretext of toll even from non-users to protect against harassment

anchor.surface_text: The contention though prima facie somewhat attractive does number stand scrutiny. Section 24 reads as under... It is obvious that this section does number speak of taking toll in excess of the lawful limit only from those persons who use the ferry.

arguments.claim: Even if case falls within mischief of extortion under IPC, does not exclude applicability of s. 24

anchor.surface_text: The question whether or number the appellants case falls within the mischief of extortion as defined under the Indian Penal Code is number strictly relevant... His liability to be prosecuted under the Indian Penal Code cannot by itself in law exclude the applicability of s. 24 to his case.

arguments.claim: Appellant delayed prosecution witnesses without due cause in crossing the river in violation of s. 24

anchor.surface_text: When the appellants counsel took us through the evidence we found that the appellant had also delayed the prosecution witnesses without due cause in crossing the river in violation of s. 24.

arguments.claim: Art. 136 does not confer right of appeal but discretionary power exercised sparingly only where grave miscarriage of justice from illegality etc.; no such infirmity here

anchor.surface_text: Finally it may be pointed out that Art. 136 of the Constitution does number confer a right of appeal on a party. It only confers a discretionary power on this Court to be exercised sparingly... The present case suffers from no such infirmity.

arguments.claim: Complainants used landing stage and path constructed and repaired by lessee, therefore liable to pay toll

anchor.surface_text: It was observed by the Additional Sessions Judge in his reference that according to the appellants defence the complainants party were in fact using the landing stage and the path constructed and repaired by him and, therefore, they were liable to pay the usual toll tax.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: the usual toll tax. After reproducing s. 24 he added . . the companyplainants case as it appears from the petition of companyplaint and also from the

arguments.court_reasoning: Complainant's evidence accepted that they did not use facilities provided by lessee

holdings.text: Section 24 of the Bengal Ferries Act applies to a lessee asking or taking more than the lawful toll even from persons who do not use the ferry, if demanded under the pretext of toll when not legally due.

anchor.surface_text: The contention though prima facie somewhat attractive does number stand scrutiny. Section 24 reads as under Penalty for taking unauthorised tolls, and for causing delay Every such lessee or other person as aforesaid asking or taking more than the lawful toll, or without due cause delaying any person, annual, vehicle or other thing, shall be punished with fine which may extend to one hundred rupees. It is obvious that this section does number speak of taking toll in excess of the lawful limit only from those persons who use the ferry.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading of s.24 does not limit to ferry users; purposive construction to prevent harassment by illegal toll demands under pretext, suppressing legislative mischief.

holdings.text: The definition of 'ferry' in s.5 is not exhaustive and does not control or limit the interpretation of s.24.

anchor.surface_text: The submission is difficult to accept. This definition which is number exhaustive does number seem to us to companytrol or otherwise to throw helpful light in the interpretation of s. 24. This section seems to have been designed in effect to protect the persons crossing the river against harassment and abuse of the privileged position which the lessee or other person authorised to companylect the tolls of a public ferry occupies under the statute

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.5 definition merely illustrative, not restricting broader protective purpose of s.24 against abuse by lessee.

holdings.text: Even if the conduct amounts to extortion under the Indian Penal Code, it does not exclude the applicability of s.24 of the Bengal Ferries Act.

anchor.surface_text: The question whether or number the appellants case falls within the mischief of extortion as defined under the Indian Penal Code is number strictly relevant... His liability to be prosecuted under the Indian Penal Code cannot by itself in law exclude the applicability of s. 24 to his case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Separate liabilities under different statutes; s.24 applicable independently to ferry toll violations.

holdings.text: Article 136 does not confer a right of appeal but discretionary power exercised sparingly only in cases of grave miscarriage of justice; no such infirmity present warranting interference.

anchor.surface_text: Finally it may be pointed out that Art. 136 of the Constitution does number companyfer a right of appeal on a party. It only companyfers a discretionary power on this Court to be exercised sparingly to interfere in suitable cases where grave miscarriage of justice has resulted from illegality or from misapprehension or mistake in reading evidence or from ignoring, excluding or illegally admitting material evidence. The present case suffers from numbersuch infirmity.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No illegality, mistake in evidence, or miscarriage justifying special leave interference; case lacks infirmities.

holdings.text: The appellant delayed prosecution witnesses without due cause in crossing the river, violating s.24.

anchor.surface_text: When the appellants companynsel took us through the evidence we found that the appellant had also delayed the prosecution witnesses without due cause in crossing the river in violation of s. 24.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct finding from review of evidence that delay occurred without cause.

holdings.text: Findings of fact by the trial magistrate on realisation of excess toll from non-users are not open to re-examination in revision proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: In regard to the companyviction under s. 24 the High Court observed that the trial Magistrate had found  i  that the appellant had been realising toll charges in excess of the scheduled rate of 20 ps. per cart and also realising such charges from persons who did number use the ferry and  ii  that though the companyplainant had number availed of the ferry and had taken the cart over the sandy bed of the river 40 ps. per cart were realised from him. These findings of fact were held number open to re-examination on revision.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Standard of review in criminal revision limits interference with trial court's factual findings.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal accordingly fails and is dismissed.

outcome.relief_summary: The appeal fails and is dismissed; no interference with High Court judgment upholding conviction under s. 24 of the Bengal Ferries Act.
